section.title: Introduction
section.para: The cron system is used to automatically run commands in the background at predefined times.
The cron.allow file specifies a list of users that are allowed to execute jobs via cron. The file does not exist by default, so all users can create cron jobs—except for those listed in cron.deny.

listitem.para: You have installed your product and your system is up and running.
The cron package is installed. If not, run zypper in cron to install it.

section.title: Restrict access to the cron daemon

procedure.para: To prevent users except for root from creating cron jobs, perform the following steps.

step.para: Allow users to create cron jobs by adding their usernames to the file:
To verify, try creating a cron job as non-root user listed in cron.allow. You should see the message:
step.screen: &prompt.user;crontab -e no crontab for &exampleuser_plain; - using an empty one
step.para: Quit the crontab editor and try the same with a user not listed in cron.allow (or before adding them to the file in step 2 of this procedure):
step.screen: &prompt.user2;crontab -e You (&exampleuserII_plain;) are not allowed to use this program (crontab) See crontab(1) for more information

section.title: Summary
section.para: You have now restricted creation of new cron jobs for non-root users.

important.title: Existing cron jobs
important.para: Implementing cron.allow only prevents users from creating new cron jobs. Existing jobs will still be run, even for users listed in cron.deny. To prevent this, create the file as described and remove existing user crontabs from the directory /var/spool/cron/tabs to ensure they are not run anymore.

section.title: Troubleshooting
section.para: When implementing /etc/cron.allow, there are basically just two problems that can occur:

varlistentry.term: A user can create a cron job although they should not.

listitem.para: Check that the username in /etc/cron.allow matches the actual username.

varlistentry.term: A user can not create cron jobs although they should.

listitem.para: If the user is correctly listed in /etc/cron.allow but cannot create new cron jobs, check if they are also listed in /etc/cron.deny. If the user appears in both files, /etc/cron.deny wins. Remove the user from the file to allow them to create cron jobs.
To further improve security, also consider restricting access to the at scheduler.

You should also consider switching to &systemd; timer units, as they allow for more powerful and reliable task execution. By default, users cannot use them to run code when they are not logged in. This limits the way users can interact with the system while not being connected to it.
